title: Why do some cotransport proteins use a concentration gradient for energy instead of ATP? - Quora

response.answer_text: Why do some cotransport proteins use a concentration gradient for energy instead of ATP? Short answer: To passively transport molecules across membranes, via their “downhill” gradient, no energy is needed (in addition to the potential energy of the gradient). Wikipedia articles: Passive transports — also called facilitated diffusion — follow an electrochemical gradient concentration “downhill,” no additional energy needed (see the left four coupled transports in the image below). Like drifting downstream (at rest) in a kayak, .Active transports — move molecules against their concentration gradient “pressure,” ATP supplies the needed energy (see the right Na+/K+-ATPase “ion pump” animation in the image below). Like paddling upstream (doing work) in a kayak. For the Na[math]^+[/math]/K[math]^+[/math] ATPase active membrane transport principles of operation, see Quora question Can Electricity be Generated by Neurons?
